newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dollar's further rise seen limited in Asia.
newsitem.headline: Dollar's further rise seen limited in Asia.

text.p: Any further advance by the dollar against the yen is expected to be limited in Asia on Friday after it rose sharply overnight, triggered by strong short-covering of the mark versus the yen, dealers said.

"The dollar/yen was largely driven by technical factors overnight, and at the same time there were no incentives to buy yen," a Japanese city bank dealer said. "But I think the dollar isn't expected to jump sharply from this level."
Activity is expected to be thin today with the dollar unlikely to find a clear direction in dollar/yen trade as many Tokyo operators are on their "Obon" summer holidays.
Dealers said strong technical resistance seen lined up around 118 yen area, while the greenback is expected to be supported around 117.30 yen after rising decisively overnight.
Dealers said that the dollar's rallies against the yen overnight were also exaggerated as many Japanese exporters and other Japanese operators were out on vacation.
Concern that a Southeast Asian currency crisis may hurt Japan's fragile economy depressed the yen overnight.
A broad yen slump commenced after Indonesia announced a de facto float of its currency on Thursday, following similar action by neighbouring countries in recent weeks.
Bundesbank vice president Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, in an interview with the German newspaper Handelsblatt, said the German central bank was concerned about inflation and wanted the freedom to act.
Gaddum also reiterated that Bundesbank policy is not driven by foreign exchange developments, but added they were keeping a close eye for any "exaggerated" moves.

Dealers said the market should be a bit cautious about selling the mark aggressively after the comments by Gaddum and the Bundesbank's monthly report on Wednesday which warned that the pace of inflation has picked up.
Dealers said that the dollar was expected to be under downward pressure should it climb above 1.8450 marks.
The mark advanced sharply overnight on heavy short-covering and stop-loss buying. A clear break above 63.50 yen also intensified the German currency's upward trend, dealers said.
However, Japanese exporters may show some selling interest in the mark above 64.00 yen. In the short term, the mark is expected to trade in a range of 63.80 to 64.30 yen.
